analyzed: jātaka  ti sa nipāta  ki chanda vagga
translated: Jātaka🔽Thirty-Third Chapter
The Chapter about Desires🔽The Pot-born Jātaka
“Who is it that stands in the sky at midday,
Shining like the moon in the firmament;
Rays issue from your limbs,
Like lightning flashes in the sky.
You walk on the water like a goose,
You go through the air and stand;

analyzed: iddhi nu te vatthukatā su bhāvitā
translated: Are your psychic powers well developed?
You are not inferior to the gods.

analyzed: vehāyasam gammam āgamma tiṭṭhasi  kumbham kiṇātha ati yam etam attha
translated: You go through the air and stand,🔽You say, ‘Buy this pot.’

original: Ko vā tuvaṁ kissa vā tāya kumbho,
analyzed: kaḥ vā tuvam kissa vā tāya kumbho
translated: Who are you, and why do you have this pot?
Brahmin, tell me the meaning of this.”
“This is not a pot of ghee or a pot of oil,

original: Na phāṇitassa na madhussa kumbho;🔽Kumbhassa vajjāni anappakāni,
analyzed: na phāṇitassa na madhussa kumbhaḥ  kumbhassa vajjāni anappakāni
translated: Nor a pot of molasses or honey;🔽The faults of the pot are many,
Listen to the many faults of the pot.
One might fall into a pit after drinking it,
Into a swamp, cave, or a deep ravine;
One might eat much that is inedible,
Buy this full pot of that.
Having drunk it, he is not mindful,
He wanders about like a cow, seeking food,
He comes to the house without being invited and dances,
Buy this full pot from him.

analyzed: yam veḥ pivitvā acelaḥ uva naggaḥ
translated: Having drunk it, he goes about naked like a naked ascetic,
Wandering about the streets,
With a confused mind, very restless,

original: Tassā puṇṇaṁ kumbhamimaṁ kiṇātha.🔽Yaṁ pitva uṭṭhāya pavedhamāno,
analyzed: tassā puṇṇam kumbham imam kiṇātha  yam pitve uṭṭhāya pavedhamānaḥ
translated: Buy this full pot from him.🔽Having drunk it, he gets up and stretches,
Shaking his head and arms,
He dances like a wooden puppet,

original: Tassā puṇṇaṁ kumbhamimaṁ kiṇātha.🔽Yaṁ ve pivitvā aggidaḍḍhā sayanti,
analyzed: tassā puṇṇam kumbham imam kiṇātha  yam ve pivitvā aggi daḍḍhā sayanti
translated: Buy this full pot from him.🔽Having drunk it, they lie down as if burned by fire,
And are eaten by jackals and snakes,

original: Bandhaṁ vadhaṁ bhogajāniñcupenti,🔽Tassā puṇṇaṁ kumbhamimaṁ kiṇātha.
analyzed: bandham vadham  tassā puṇṇam kumbham imam kiṇātha
translated: They fall into bondage, killing, and the suffering of losing their wealth,🔽Buy this full pot from him.

analyzed: yam pitva bhāseyya a bhāsaneyya  sabhāyam āsīnaḥ apetavatthaḥ
translated: Having drunk it, he would speak what should not be spoken,🔽Sitting in the assembly, with his clothes removed,
Covered in mud, gone astray, fallen into misfortune,
Buy this full pot from him.
Having drunk it, he becomes arrogant and agitated,

analyzed: mama eva sabbā pathavī iti maññe
translated: Thinking, The whole earth is mine alone,
“There is no king equal to me in the four directions.
Buy this full jar from me.

analyzed: māna ati mānā kalahāni pesuṇī  dubbaṇṇinī naggayinī palāyinī
translated: “Pride, overweening pride, quarrels, slander,🔽Bad complexion, scolding, running away,
The course and abode of thieves and rogues,
Buy this full jar from me.
“There are prosperous and wealthy families,

analyzed: aneka sāhassa dhanāni loke  ucchinna dāyajjaka tā nimāya
translated: In the world with many thousands of riches.🔽For them, the giving of gifts is cut off.
Buy this full jar from me.
“Grain, wealth, silver, and gold,
Fields and cattle, where they are destroyed,
The cutting off of the wealth of families,
Buy this full jar from me.

analyzed: yam ve pitvā ditta rūpā uva poso
translated: “Having drunk from which a man becomes like one possessed,
He reviles his mother and father.
He would take his own mother and sister,
Buy this full jar from me.

original: Yaṁ ve pitvā dittarūpāva nārī,🔽Akkosatī sasuraṁ sāmikañca;
analyzed: yam ve pitvā ditta rūpā ava nārī  akkosatī sa suram sāmikam ca
translated: “Having drunk from which a woman becomes like one possessed,🔽She reviles her father-in-law and husband.
She would take a slave and a servant,
Buy this full jar from me.
Having drunk which a man might die,
Having drunk which a man might kill a holy man or a brahman who abides in Dhamma,
And because of that go to the nether regions,

original: Tassā puṇṇaṁ kumbhamimaṁ kiṇātha.🔽Yaṁ ve pivitvā duccaritaṁ caranti,
analyzed: tassā puṇṇam kumbham imam kiṇātha  yam ve pivitvā duccaritam caranti
translated: Buy this jar full of that.
Having drunk which they do bad actions with body, speech, and mind,
Having done bad actions they go to hell,
Buy this jar full of that.
Having drunk which they do not get what they ask for in the past,
Even though they give away much gold,
Having drunk that he speaks falsely,
Buy this jar full of that.
Having drunk which he sends a messenger to a distant place,
When an urgent matter has arisen,

analyzed: attham pi so na pajānāti vuttaḥ
translated: And when told he does not understand the meaning,
Buy this jar full of that.
Even those who are ashamed become shameless,
Drunk with intoxication they do bad things,
Even the wise speak much,
Buy this jar full of that.
Having drunk which they lie down in one place in a heap,
Without attachment, on a bare ground bed,
The ugly, the sickly, the deformed,
Buy this jar full of it.

original: Yaṁ ve pitvā pattakhandhā sayanti,🔽Gāvo kuṭahatāva na hi vāruṇiyā;
analyzed: yam ve pitvā patta khandhā sayanti  gāvaḥ na hi vāruṇiyā
translated: Having drunk which, the strong-limbed lie down,🔽Like cows beaten with a stick, not from intoxication;
Like a strong current a man cannot cross,
Buy this jar full of it.
Which men avoid,
Like a snake, a terrible poison,
That which is like poison in the world,
What man is able to drink?

analyzed: yam ve pitvā andhaka veṇḍa puttā
translated: Having drunk which, the Andhakas and Veṇḍaka sons,
While wandering on the ocean shore;
Attacked each other with clubs and stones,
Buy this jar full of it.

original: Yaṁ ve pitvā pubbadevā pamattā,🔽Tidivā cutā sassatiyā samāya;
analyzed: yam ve pitvā pubbadevā pamattā  tidivā cutā sassatiyā samāya
translated: Having drunk which, the careless former gods,🔽Having fallen from the Heavenly World after a hundred years;
That such a useless liquor,
Knowing, Great King, how could one drink?

original: Nayimasmiṁ kumbhasmiṁ dadhi vā madhu vā,
translated: There is no curd or honey in this jar,
Having understood thus buy it, King;

analyzed: evam hi imam kumbha gatāḥ mayā te
translated: Thus this jar full of it is yours,
All of it, my friend, has been described to you.”

analyzed: na me pitā vā athavā api mātā
translated: “Neither my father nor my mother,
Such as you are,
You are full of pity and desire the highest good.
Therefore I will do as you ask.
I give you five choice villages,
A hundred female slaves, seven hundred cows,

analyzed: ājañña yutte ca rathe dasa ime
translated: And these ten chariots with thoroughbred horses yoked to them.
Be my teacher, you who desire my good.”

original: “Taveva dāsīsatamatthu rāja,🔽Gāmā ca gāvo ca taveva hontu;
analyzed: tava iva rāja  gāmā ca gāvaḥ ca tava iva hontu
translated: “Let the hundred female slaves be yours, O King,🔽Let the villages and cows be yours,

analyzed: ājañña yuttā ca rathā tava iva
translated: And the chariots with thoroughbred horses yoked to them be yours.

analyzed: sakkā uham asmi tidasānam indo  masodanam sappi pāyāsam bhuñja
translated: I am Sakka, the lord of the Thirty-three.🔽Eat the flesh of the boar and the rice cooked in milk,

analyzed: khādassu ca tvam madhu māsa pūve
translated: And eat the cakes of honey and molasses.
Thus, O King, delighting in the Dhamma,
Go to heaven, blameless one.”
The Kumbha Jātaka (second).
